Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Responding to extreme heat in the time of COVID-19

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Responding to extreme heat conditions during the COVID-19 pandemic could place many vulnerable populations at further risk during the warm summer months when many people leave their houses to escape the heat and visit cooling centers and other public spaces. People’s vulnerability is likely to vary over time and space, shifting with the extent of exposure to extreme heat, differences in policy and community response, and disease pressure from COVID-19. By assessing experiences, risk perceptions, behaviors, and perceived ability to respond to these conditions, the investigators will improve the understanding of how people cope with and adapt to multiple evolving hazards. The project will contribute to broader efforts to understand and reduce population health risks from extreme weather events during a global pandemic. The project’s findings will be broadly disseminated to researchers, public health and emergency management practitioners, and the public. <br/><br/>This project brings together theory and methods from geography and behavioral sciences to develop new knowledge about the interactions among people, their environment, and multiple evolving hazards. This research will build on existing theoretical foundations and empirical knowledge and will examine how extreme weather conditions, COVID-19, local policies, and environmental and socio-demographic characteristics affect the public’s risk perceptions, behaviors, and ability to take protective measures. The investigators will conduct a series of georeferenced nationally representative surveys combined with spatially explicit modeling with questions about COVID-19 and extreme heat risk perceptions and experiences, self-reported symptoms of heat stress and COVID-19, household coping capacity, self-efficacy, and protective behaviors undertaken to reduce vulnerability. The project findings will inform risk communication and public health intervention strategies aimed at reducing extreme heat and COVID-19-related impacts that can be generalized for other multi-hazard events.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to understand how the COVID-19 pandemic affected the extreme heat experiences, risk perceptions, coping strategies, and behaviors of the U.S. population. To do so, we conducted a three-wave nationally representative survey in July, August, and September 2020 with 3,036 adult (18+) U.S. residents. We analyzed the survey responses to identify overall patterns in how Americans experienced and responded to the combined effects of the COVID-19 pandemic and hot weather during summer 2020. We also used statistical models to understand 1) how sociodemographic and pandemic-related factors were associated with negative health effects from extreme heat, and 2) how risk perceptions of heat and COVID-19 varied geographically and across demographic groups. 

Key findings included the following: more than half of all American adults expressed some degree of worry about the effects of heat waves (58%) and COVID-19 (82%) on their health in summer 2020. More than a quarter (28%) reported having one or more health symptoms that they believed were related to extreme heat, and more than one in eight reported feeling too hot at home (14.7%) or experiencing decreased productivity while working (12.5%). Over a quarter (25.8%) of U.S. residents either did not have air conditioning or could not cool their homes effectively. People who were unemployed or in low-income households, and those who identified as Hispanic or Latino, were most likely to report experiencing negative effects from heat exposure. The COVID-19 pandemic also magnified social isolation, a risk factor during extreme heat events: 75% of U.S. residents indicated at least one change in behavior due to the pandemic that contributed to social isolation. 

Our project also developed maps of how the U.S. public perceived the dual risks of extreme heat and COVID-19 during the summer of 2020. We showed that risk perceptions of extreme heat and COVID-19 varied across states and across demographic groups, with differences in risk perceptions similar to health disparities for each risk. People who face greater health impacts from both COVID-19 and extreme heat due to institutional and societal inequalities, including Black or African American and Hispanic or Latino populations, were also much more worried about both risks than white, non-Hispanic populations. Risk perceptions also tended to be associated with underlying external factors associated with the risk environment, including local climate (for extreme heat) and mortality rates (for COVID-19).
